subs.text:
I was an Apple dev when Steve Jobs came back.

He made big changes at Apple. People didn't like it, journalists said it was suicidal when he killed the clones that they forced Apple to create.

And after that he fixed the Mac, simplified the product line, iPod, iPhone, etc.
subs.rawText:
I was an Apple dev when Steve Jobs came back.

He made big changes at Apple. People didn't like it, journalists said it was suicidal when he killed the clones that they forced Apple to create.

And after that he fixed the Mac, simplified the product line, iPod, iPhone, etc.

subs.text: BTW, tangentially -- some of the things he did really sucked and might've helped Apple be even more dominant, it certainly would have let the web develop more on the Mac, and thus change would have come sooner.
subs.rawText: BTW, tangentially -- some of the things he did really sucked and might've helped Apple be even more dominant, it certainly would have let the web develop more on the Mac, and thus change would have come sooner.

subs.text: In 1997 we were just starting to blog. That was the year RSS first came out. Our paths would cross again with podcasting. How much easier this would have been if we could have stuck to one platform. Whatever all water under the bridge.
subs.rawText: In 1997 we were just starting to blog. That was the year RSS first came out. Our paths would cross again with podcasting. How much easier this would have been if we could have stuck to one platform. Whatever all water under the bridge.

subs.text: Musk coming into Twitter will definitely shake things up much like Jobs coming to Apple in 1997 did. But as Om says, things aren't going very well over here in TwitterLand. Breaking down some barriers would be great. And giving up on things that didn't work also would be great.

subs.text: 2/9 For one thing, none of the CEOs of Twitter going back to the beginning were natural bloggers. Musk is.

subs.text: 3/9 When he was joining the board, I thought that was good because having a user on the board of a tech company is pretty unusual, and would be a good thing. Having a user as the CEO -- even better.
subs.rawText: 3/9 When he was joining the board, I thought that was good because having a user on the board of a tech company is pretty unusual, and would be a good thing. Having a user as the CEO -- even better.

subs.text: 4/9 Also there's too much religion in the UI of Twitter. Musk's ideas were pragmatic. On the right path, imho.
subs.rawText: 4/9 Also there's too much religion in the UI of Twitter. Musk's ideas were pragmatic. On the right path, imho.

subs.text: 5/9 I am a customer of Tesla and StarLink, and both companies appear to be run well, and what they do is imho harder than running Twitter, which basically is the kind of service the tech industry is good at running.

subs.text: 6/9 My main concern with Musk as the new owner of Twitter is that Trump will be back. I think it was proven beyond any doubt that Twitter can be grossly misused, and the company has to be ready to stop its service from being used in such a harmful way.
subs.rawText: 6/9 My main concern with Musk as the new owner of Twitter is that Trump will be back. I think it was proven beyond any doubt that Twitter can be grossly misused, and the company has to be ready to stop its service from being used in such a harmful way.

subs.text: 7/9 Free speech is not an absolute -- the old Yelling Fire in a crowded movie theater idea. Trump used Twitter to organize the overthrow of the US government and almost succeeded at it.
subs.rawText: 7/9 Free speech is not an absolute -- the old Yelling Fire in a crowded movie theater idea. Trump used Twitter to organize the overthrow of the US government and almost succeeded at it.

subs.text: 8/9 I am also concerned that Musk will curtail the Twitter API, which is incredibly useful and under-exploited by the company and its users. I've built a lot of tech on top of the API, and would miss it if it were gone.

subs.text: 2/3 I eased up on my evangelism for OPML because the various teams in #tft seem busy focused on their own products, and aren't thinking a lot about interop these days, I guess. So I got to work on another project, but I'll be coming back to this. I do not give up easily. :-)

Did you know Twitter is a feed reader?

But why haven't RSS-based feed readers evolved to work like Twitter?

@TaylorLorenz Taylor, I was for a while the center of the blogging world, and all the abuse we were gathering was aimed at me. 

People would figure out who I was dating, and then go after them. Same for the people who worked with me.
subs.rawText:
@TaylorLorenz Taylor, I was for a while the center of the blogging world, and all the abuse we were gathering was aimed at me. 

People would figure out who I was dating, and then go after them. Same for the people who worked with me.

subs.text:
@TaylorLorenz Eventually I deliberately cut down on my fame. To take the focus off me. A lifestyle choice. 

I don't know that there's any other way out of the problem. Writing about it publicly only makes it worse I found. Very little sympathy out there for the person at or near the top.
subs.rawText:
